docs.title: Languages I like
docs.text:
Personal notes & resources for languages I like:

Guarani

Aymara

Gününa a iajuch

Quechua

Many other languages... but I have not created the files yet.

docs.title: Aymara
docs.text: Person Singular Dual Plural 1st person excl. naya ? nanaka 1st person incl. – ? jiwasanaka 2nd person juma ? jumanaka 3rd person jupa ? jupanaka

docs.title: Possessives
docs.text:
-ja POSS.1sg

-ma POSS.2sg

-pa POSS.3sg

docs.title: Other words
docs.text:
Kuna 'what'

Kawki 'where'

khiti 'who'

qawqha 'how much'

kamisa 'how'

docs.title: Affixes
docs.text:
-sa 'information'

-xa 'sentence'

-wa 'sentence'

-ti 'interrogation'

-sti 'y'

-ta 'from'

-ru 'to'

-na 'en'

-na 'from'

-ka- 'verb'

kuna-sa → kunas 'what'

docs.title: Guarani
docs.text: Person Singular Plural Notes 1st (inclusive) — ñande "we (inclusive)": includes the person spoken to 1st (exclusive) che ore "I" and "we (exclusive)": does not include the listener 2nd nde peẽ "you (singular)" and "you (plural)" 3rd haʼe haʼekuéra "he/she/it" and "they"

docs.title: 1. Subject prefixes for transitive verbs (Active agreement)
docs.text: Person Prefix Example Gloss 1st singular a- ajapo ‘I do it’ 2nd singular re- rejapo ‘you do it’ 3rd singular o- ojapo ‘he/she does it’ 1st plural incl. ja- jajapo ‘we (incl.) do it’ 1st plural incl. (Nasal bases) ña- ñag̃uahẽ 'we (incl) arrive' 1st plural excl. ro- rojapo ‘we (excl.) do it’ 2nd plural pe- pejapo ‘you (pl.) do it’ 3rd plural o- ojapo ‘they do it’

docs.title: 2. Subject markers for intransitive/stative verbs
docs.text: Person Prefix Example Gloss 1st singular che- chekane ‘I am tired’ 2nd singular nde- ndekane ‘you are tired’ 3rd singular o- okane ‘he/she is tired’ 1st plural incl. ñande- ñandekane ‘we (incl.) are tired’ 1st plural excl. ore- orekane ‘we (excl.) are tired’ 2nd plural peẽ- peẽkane ‘you (pl.) are tired’ 3rd plural o- okane ‘they are tired’

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Person Active Prefix Stative/Possessive Prefix 1SG a- che- 2SG re- nde- 3SG o- o- 1PL.INCL ña- ñande- 1PL.EXCL ro- ore- 2PL pe- peẽ- 3PL o- o-

Here's your vocabulary list in well-structured Markdown format:

docs.title: jogua ‘comprar’
docs.text: Ejs.: ajogua ‘compro’; rejogua ‘comprás’; ojogua ‘compra’

docs.title: mbojy ‘cocer, cocinar’
docs.text: Ejs.: ambojy ‘cocino’; rembojy ‘cocinas’; ñambojy ‘cocinamos’

docs.title: ha’u ‘comer/beber’
docs.text: Ejs.: ha’u ‘como’; re’u ‘comés’; ho’u ‘come’; pe’u ‘coméis’; ja’u ‘comemos’

docs.title: ñe’ẽ ‘hablar’
docs.text: Ejs.: añe’ẽ ‘hablo’; reñe’ẽ ‘hablás’; oñe’ẽ ‘habla’

docs.title: moñe’ẽ ‘leer’
docs.text: Ejs.: amoñe’ẽ ‘leo’; remoñe’ẽ ‘leés’; omoñe’ẽ ‘lee’; ñamoñe’ẽ / romoñe’ẽ ‘leemos’

docs.title: hai ‘escribir’
docs.text: Ejs.: ahai ‘escribo’; rehai ‘escribís’; ohai ‘escribe’; rohai / jahai ‘escribimos’

docs.title: y’u ‘beber agua’
docs.text: Ejs.: hay’u ‘bebo agua’; rey’u ‘bebés agua’; hoy’u ‘bebe agua’; jay’u / roy’u ‘bebemos agua’

docs.title: ’u ‘comer’
docs.text: Ejs.: ha’u ‘como’; re’u ‘comés’; ho’u ‘come’; ro’u / ja’u ‘comemos’

docs.title: ho ‘ir’
docs.text: Conj.: aha, rejo, oho, jaha, roho, peho

docs.title: ju ‘venir’
docs.text: Conj.: ayu, reju, ou, jaju, roju, peju

docs.title: ‘e ‘decir’
docs.text: Conj.: ha’e, ere, he’i, ja’e, ro’e, peje

docs.title: veve ‘volar’
docs.text: Ej.: Peteĩ guyra oveve. ‘Un pájaro vuela.’

docs.title: guata ‘caminar’
docs.text: Ej.: aguata, reguata, oguata

docs.title: ñani ‘correr’
docs.text: Ej.: añani, ñeñani, oñani Ej.: Mborerotochukuéra oñani. ‘Los elefantes corren.’

docs.title: ñarõ ‘ladrar’
docs.text: Ej.: oñarõ ‘ladra’

docs.title: reko ‘tener’
docs.text: Ej.: areko ‘tengo’ Ej.: Che areko heta mbarakaja. ‘Yo tengo muchos gatos.’

docs.text:
• eiratã ‘azúcar’

  • avati ‘maíz’
  • pakova ‘banana’

  • jukysy ‘sopa’
  • so’o ‘carne’
  • merõ ‘melón’
  • kesu ‘queso’
  • fideo ‘fideo(s)’
  • he’ẽ asuka ‘dulce, azucarado’
  • he’ẽ juky ‘salado/a’
  • avati’i ‘arroz’
  • pira ‘pescado’
  • ryguasu ‘pollo, gallina’
  • rupi’a ‘huevo’
  • kaguy ‘vino’
  • mbujape ‘pan’
  • kamby ‘leche’

docs.title: Personas
docs.text:
• mitã ‘niño’
  • mitã’i ‘niñito’
  • mitã'ikuéra / mitãnguéra ‘los niños’
  • mitãkuña ‘niña’
  • mitãkuña’i ‘niñita’
  • mitãkuña'ikuéra ‘las niñas’
  • mitãkaria’y / karia’y ‘muchacho’
  • kuimba’e ‘hombre’
  • kuimba'ekuéra ‘los hombres’
  • kuñataĩ ‘señorita’
  • kuñakarai ‘señora’
  • kuña ‘mujer’
  • kuñanguéra ‘las mujeres’
  • karai ‘señor’
  • yvypóra ‘persona’

docs.title: Animales
docs.text:
• mborerotochu ‘elefante’

  • mbarakaja ‘gato’

  • Ej.: Ko mbarakaja ha’e chemba’e.

  • jagua ‘perro’

  • Ej.: Jaguakuéra oñani.

  • ype ‘pato’
  • kavaju ‘caballo’
  • karumbe ‘tortuga’
  • vaka ‘vaca’
  • kure ‘cerdo’
  • guyra ‘pájaro’

  • ñandu ‘araña’

  • Ej.: Guyrakuéra ho’u peteĩ ñandu.

  • mberu ‘mosca’

  • ñati’ũ ‘mosquito’

  • Ej.: Oveve ñati’ũ?

  • mymba ‘animal’

  • Ej.: mymbakuéra ‘animales’; heta mymba oñani

  • leõ ‘león’
  • tapiti ‘conejo’
  • anguja ‘ratón’
  • ka’i ‘mono’
  • vakame ‘toro’

docs.title: Lenguas y escritura
docs.text:
• avañe’ẽ ‘idioma guaraní’
  • guaraníme / avañe’ẽme ‘en guaraní’
  • guaraniñe’ẽ ‘guaraní’
  • ingyaterrañe’ẽ ‘inglés’
  • karaiñe’ẽ ‘español’
  • kuatiañe’ẽ ‘carta’
  • kuatiahaipyre ‘periódico’
  • momaranduha ‘diario’
  • aranduka ‘libro’

docs.title: 🏠 Otros
docs.text:
• óga ‘casa’
  • pa’ã ‘problema’
  • ñane ‘nuestro (incl.)’

  • ore ‘nosotros/as (excl.)’

  • Ej.: Ore mymba

  • peẽ ‘ustedes, vosotros’
  • ha’ekuéra ‘ellos, ellas’
  • amo ‘allá’
  • i / ne / che / nde / pende ‘posesivos: su, tu, mi, vos, vuestro’
  • mba’e ‘cosa, qué, pertenencia’
  • peteĩ ‘uno, una’
  • pe / ko / amo ‘ese, este, aquel’
  • pene ‘posesivo: de ustedes, vuestro’

docs.title: ✨ Adjetivos
docs.text:
• juky ‘tierno, simpático, gracioso, atractivo, saleroso’

  • iporã ‘está buena/linda’

  • Ej.: Vakakuéra iporã

  • iporãnte ‘bien nomás’
  • ivai ‘feo’
  • he’ẽ ‘dulce’
  • juky (en compuestos) ‘salado’

docs.title: 💬 Expresiones y partículas
docs.text:
• heẽ ‘sí’
  • nahániri ‘no’
  • ndaha’éi ‘no es’
  • ndaipóri ‘no hay’
  • mba’éichapa ‘¿cómo estás?, ¿cómo?’
  • aguyje ‘gracias’
  • jajohecha peve ‘nos vemos’

  • piko ‘¿?, enfático’

  • Ej.: Pene mbarakaja piko ho’u kamby?

  • hína ‘partícula enfatizadora’
  • ko’ẽ ‘amanecer’
  • pyhareve ‘mañana’
  • pyhare ‘noche’
  • asaje ‘siesta’
  • ha ‘y, e’

  • heta

  • adj. ‘muchas, varias’

  • adv. ‘mucho’
  • Ej.: Peteĩ leõ oñani heta.

docs.title: Günün a iajüch
docs.text: Some morphosyntactic paradigms in Günan a iajüch:

docs.title: Consonants
docs.text:
Labial Dental Alveolo-palatal Velar Glottal voiceless stop p (p) t (t) tɹ (tr), tʃ (ch) k (k) ʔ (ʔ) voiced stop b (b) d (d) g (g) nasal m (m) n (n) tap/trill r (r) fricative s (s) ʂ (ş) x (x) approximant j (y) w (w) lateral ɬ (ł), l (l)
  • tɹ (tr), ʂ (ş), j (y), ɬ (ł) and l (l) are described as apical; while tʃ (ch) as laminal.

docs.title: Vowels
docs.text:
front central back high i ɨ (ü) u mid e low a
  • /ɨ/ is sometimes written <ï>

docs.title: Posssives
docs.text: singular dual plural POS-1 -k-i-a -k-ş-üp -kü-şü-na POS-1-SG POS-1-DU POS-1-PL POS-2 -k-m-a -k-m-üp kü-mü-na POS-2-SG POS-2-DU POS-2-PL POS-3 -k-ø-a -k-ø-üp -ø-pü-n POS-3-SG POS-3-DU POS-3-PL

docs.title: Personal Pronouns and posessive markers
docs.text: personales posesivos alienables 1. sg k-w-a -k-i-a 2. sg kü-m-aw -kü-m-a 3. sg şaşe -k-ø-a 1. du kü-ş-aw -k-ş-üp 2. du kü-m-aw -k-m-up 3. du w-aw -k-üp 1. pl küşan -kü-şü-na 2. pl kümap -kü-müna 3. pl şaşe -pün

docs.title: Person markers
docs.text: Person Singular Dual Plural 1st ø ş ş 2nd m m m 3rd ø w ka

docs.title: Object markers
docs.text: Person Singular Dual Plural 1st -kja -kjüp -kşün 2nd -kma -kmiüp -kmiün 3rd -ka -küp -pün

docs.title: References
docs.text: Orden, M. E. (2017). Descripción de la lengua Günün a Iajüch [Doctorado en Letras]. Universidad Nacional del Sur.

docs.title: Phonology
docs.text: Front Central Back Closed (High) i u Open (Low) a

docs.title: Consonants
docs.text: Labial Alveolar Retroflex Palatal Velar Uvular Voiceless plosive p t tr [ʈ] ch [c] k q Voiced plosive (b) (d) (g) Nasal m n ñ [ɲ] Trill (rr)[r] Tap or Flap r [ɾ] Voiceless fric. (f) s sh [ʃ] h Voiced fricative (v) Approximant w y [j] Lat. approximant l ll [ʎ]

docs.title: Personal Pronouns
docs.text: Person Singular Plural 1 ñuqa ñuqa-nchik (dual) ñuqa-nchik-kuna (inclusive) ñuqa-kuna (exclusive) 2 qam qam-kuna 3 pay pay-kuna

docs.title: Case Suffixes in syq
docs.text:
• -hina – comparative

  • -kama – limitative

  • -man – allative, dative

  • -pa – genitive, locative

  • -pi – locative

  • -paq – ablative, benefactive, purposive

  • -puRa – reciprocal (rare, only in Viñac)

  • -rayku – reason (rare)

  • -ta – accusative (realized as -kta after short vowels in the ch dialect)

  • -wan – comitative, instrumental

  • -traw – locative (used only in the ch dialect; common in qi languages)

docs.title: References
docs.text: Shimelman, A. (2017). A grammar of Yauyos Quechua (Studies in Diversity Linguistics 9). Berlin: Language Science Press.
